Detailed Description

template<class T, typename VerifyPolicy = AutoVerify>
class amop::TMockObject< T, VerifyPolicy >

The main mock object class.

TMockObject is a template class for mocking your interface.

Initialization

Let's say your want to mock a interface:

            class IInterface
            {
            public:                
                
                virtual void Foo1() = 0;
                virtual void Foo2(size_t i, const std::string& s) = 0;
                virtual size_t Foo3() = 0;
                virtual size_t Foo4(size_t i) = 0;
            };

To create your mock object: 

            TMockObject<IInterface> mock;

The IInterface is what interface you want to mock with and it should be a pure virtual class (No member variables, No non-virtual member functions).

Usage

After that, you can treat it as a smart pointer of your interface, putting it into your testing functions directly.

            // The functions to test
            void functionToTest(IInterface*);           
            void functionToTestByRef(IInterface&);
            
            // In your test:          
            functionToTest(mock);
            functionToTestByRef(*mock);

Bindings

TMockObject support 4 types of function binding modes: Call Mode, EveryCall Mode, Query Mode, Redirect Mode. But all the usage of this modes are the same:

            TMockObject<IInterface> mock;
            
            mock.EveryCall(&IInterface::Foo2).Expect(10, "String");
            
            mock.Call(&IInterface::Foo3).Return(20);
            
            mock.Redirect(&IInterface::Foo4).Do(&SomeOtherFunction);          
            
            size_t numberOfCalls = mock.Query(&IInterface::Foo4).Count();

After you binded your functions to the mock object, you can peform verify the arguments, query the number of times the function called and redirect it to your own function etc., according the modes you choosed.

And you can mix these modes together by calling it twice:

            // The IInterface::Foo4 will return 10 every times
            mock.EveryCall(&IInterface::Foo4).Return(10);
            
            // The &IInterface::Foo4 expect 10, and then 20
            mock.Call(&IInterface::Foo4)
                .Expect(10)
                .Expect(20);

Call Mode

In this mode, your can verify the arguments, setting the return values of your function. The number of calls must match exactly, each call has distinct arguments that it shall verify against, and distinct return values it shall mock. When the expectation is not corrected, an exception will be thrown:

            mock.Call(&IInterface::Foo4)
                .Expect(10).Return(1)
                .Expect(20).Return(2);          
            
            // We use UnitTest++ here, but you can use any unit-test library with amop.
            CHECK(1, mock->Foo4(10));
            CHECK(2, mock->Foo4(20));

            CHECK_THROW(mock->Foo4(30), TCallCountException);

The TMockObject::Call method will bind your given method to Call mode, and it will return an object, which you can call its method to setting the behaviors of given function when it is mocked. Please reference Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TCallPolicy> for its usage.

See also:
TMockObject::Call

Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TCallPolicy>

EveryCall Mode

The EveryCall mode is very similar to Call Mode , except verify arguments an infinite number of times, and shall not care about number of calls:

            mock.EveryCall(&Interface::Foo4)
                .Expect(10).Return(1)

            CHECK(1, mock->Foo4(10);
            CHECK(1, mock->Foo4(10);
            CHECK(1, mock->Foo4(10);
            CHECK(1, mock->Foo4(10);

The TMockObject::EveryCall method will return an object in EveryCall mode, which you can setting the behaviors like TMockObject::Call return object does. Please reference Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TEveryCallPolicy> for its usage.

See also:
TMockObject::EveryCall

Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TEveryCallPolicy>

Query Mode

The Query Mode is used for getting the function's propeties for mocking (Like the number of calls):

            mock.EveryCall(&Inteface::Foo4).Return(1)

            mock->Foo4(10);
            mock->Foo4(10);
            mock->Foo4(10);
            mock->Foo4(10);
            mock->Foo4(10);

            CHECK(5, mock.Query(&Interface::Foo4).Count())

Please reference Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TQueryPolicy> for its usage.

See also:
TMockObject::Query

Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TQueryPolicy>

Redirect Mode

You can use to redirect your function to given function:

            size_t some_other_func(size_t i);

            mock.Redirect(&Interface::Foo4).Do(&some_other_function);
        \end

        Not only the free function, even a member function it can be redirected. 
        Please reference Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TRedirectPolicy> for its usage.

        \sa TMockObject::Redirect
        \sa Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TRedirectPolicy>                

        \subsection ss_destructor Binding to destructor
        
        In some case, your will want to mock the destructor of a interface,
        your can use the trait object Destructor:

        \code
            mock.Call(Destructor());

Remarks:
In fact, it is not binding to your constructor directly, but it is binding to the delete operator of your interface. However, because it is a pure virutal class, there are only 2 way to call the destructor, one is delete it by using the delete operator, another one is call it directly ( mock->~IInterface() ). Normally latter method is rarely happened.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

template<class T, typename VerifyPolicy = AutoVerify>
template<class F>
Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, typename Detail::TCallPolicy> amop::TMockObject< T, VerifyPolicy >::Call ( F  method  )  [inline]

Create the Call Mode binding.

This function create the Call Mode binding. The Call Mode is used for verify and setting arguments for each calls, which the number of calls must match exactly.

Parameters:
method The method to be binding with
Returns:
The builder object for setting the behavior the given method.
See also:
Call Mode, Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TCallPolicy>

Create the Call Mode binding for destructor.

This function create the Call Mode binding for destructor. The Call Mode is used for verify and setting arguments for each calls, which the number of calls must match exactly. To binding a function to destructor, using the Destructor() trait object.

Returns:
The builder object for setting the behavior the given method.
See also:
Call Mode, ss_destructor, Detail::TReturnMatchBuilder<F, Detail::TCallPolicy>
